fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Grp is regular.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Handbook of categorical algebra
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{borceux-1994, place = {Cambridge}, series = {Encyclopedia of Mathematics and its Applications}, title = {Handbook of Categorical Algebra}, publisher = {Cambridge University Press}, author = {Borceux, Francis}, year = {1994}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Handbook of Categorical Algebra is designed to give, in three volumes, a detailed account of what should be known by everybody working in, or using, category theory. As such it will be a unique reference. The volumes are written in sequence, with the first being essentially self-contained, and are accessible to graduate students with a good background in mathematics.

Volume 1, which is devoted to general concepts, can be used for advanced undergraduate courses on category theory. After introducing the terminology and proving the fundamental results concerning limits, adjoint functors and Kan extensions, the categories of fractions are studied in detail; special consideration is paid to the case of localizations. The remainder of the first volume studies various 'refinements' of the fundamental concepts of category and functor.

The second, which assumes familiarity with the material in the first, introduces important classes of categories that have played a fundamental role in the subject's development and applications. In addition, after several chapters discussing specific categories, the book develops all the major concepts concerning Benabou's ideas of fibred categories. There is ample material here for a graduate course in category theory, and the book should also serve as a reference for users.

Volume 3 begins with the essential aspects of the theory of locales, proceeding to a study in chapter 2 of the sheaves on a locale and on a topological space, in their various equivalent presentations: functors, etale maps or W-sets. Next, this situation is generalized to the case of sheaves on a site and the corresponding notion of Grothendieck topos is introduced. Chapter 4 relates the theory of Grothendieck toposes with that of accessible categories and sketches, by proving the existence of a classifying topos for all coherent theories.
A group is a set equipped with an associative, unital binary operation and inverses.
Let A be a set. Then the symmetric group S_A is the group of automorphisms of A under composition. The symmetric group of a finite ordinal n is denoted S_n.
The dihedral group D_n is the group of symmetries of a regular n-gon.
The cyclic group C_n is the group of integers under the relation a\sim n whenever a - b divides n.
A subgroup is a subobject in Grp, written H\leq G; equivalently, it is a subset closed under the group operations.
By the connection between monoids and categories, a group is a groupoid with one object.
A group homomorphism G\xrightarrow {f} H is a set-function f so that, for any g, h\in G, f(gh) = f(g)f(h).
The category of groups Grp is the category whose objects are groups and whose morphisms are homomorphisms.
By the general adjoint functor theorem, the forgetful functor Grp \xrightarrow {U} Set admits a left adjoint, called the free group functor.

The forgetful functor creates limits, by a straightforward diagram chase. Moreover, for any set x, a solution set consists of (the isomorphism classes of) those groups with sufficiently small cardinalities so that they may be generated by the image of x into some UG. Indeed, because x has some fixed cardinality, this set is (essentially) small.

The free group on a set X is the group whose elements are group words in X, i.e. finite strings x_1^{\epsilon _1}\dots x_r^{\epsilon _r}, where x_i\in i and \epsilon _i\in \{-1, 1\}, modulo the relation generated by reducing adjacent pairs x^{\pm 1}x^{\mp 1}, with multiplication by concatenation.
By the monadicity theorem, the free-forgetful adjunction between Set and Grp is monadic.
As for any monadic category, Grp is complete, and moreover its limits are created from Set.

The trivial group is the zero object in Grp. Explicitly, it is the unique group on the singleton. The associated zero map is called the trivial map; explicitly, it is the constant homomorphism at the identity.
The product group is the product in Grp. Explicitly, its underlying set is the cartesian product, with operations componentwise.
The kernel of a group homomorphism G\xrightarrow {f} H is the inverse image of the identity e\in H.
The image of a group homomorphism is the underlying set-theoretic image.
To show the first two, note that monos are limits and limits are created in Set.

To show the kernel result, note that if f is injective, then the kernel is automatically trivial, whereas if f has trivial kernel, then for any x, y\in G with f(x) = f(y), f(xy^{-1}) = e, so xy^{-1}\in \ker (f), meaning xy^{-1} = e, and now x = y.
An epimorphism of groups is just a surjective homomorphism.
First, if G\xrightarrow {e} H is a surjective homomorphism, then given homomorphisms H\overset {f, g}{\rightrightarrows } K, we have that f = g because e is an epi in Set, so e is an epi.

Second, let G\xrightarrow {e} H be an epi in Grp. We wish to find a group K and two maps H\overset {f, g}{\rightrightarrows } K which agree on the image of e, hence are equal, in such a way that their equality allows us to conclude surjectivity of e. Let K be the symmetric group of the set of cosets H/e(G) with an adjoined point *.

Let H\xrightarrow {f} K be the map which sends h\in H to the associated permutation acting on kH by left translation and fixing *. Let \sigma \in K be the permutation which exchanges e(G) and *; let g be f composed with the inner automorphism associated to \sigma .

We finally claim that f(e(a)) = g(e(a)) for each a\in G. Indeed, since e(a)\in e(G), e(a) fixes e(G) and *, so is fixed under conjugation by \sigma . Now since e is an epi, f = g. Thus for each b\in H, f(b) = g(b), so that g(b) fixes f(H), i.e. bf(H) = f(H), so b\in f(H), as desired.

A (left) action of a group G on a set X is a homomorphism from G to the automorphism group of X. By uncurrying in Set, this is equivalently a map G\times X\xrightarrow {\cdot } X so that e\cdot x = x \text { and }(gh)\cdot x = g\cdot (h\cdot x). A set equipped with a G-action is called a G-set.
The (left) translation action of a group on itself is the action given by multiplication, g\cdot h = gh.

The conjugation action of a group on itself is the action given by conjugation, g\cdot h = h^g := ghg^{-1}. The automorphism associated to an element g is called the inner automorphism \operatorname *{inn}_g.
A group action of G on A is faithful if the map G\to S_A is a monomorphism.
The orbit of an element a\in A of a G-set A is the image of a under G, i.e. Ga := \{g\cdot a: g\in G\}; by invertibility in G, the orbits form an equivalence relation.
A (left) coset of a subgroup H\leq G is an orbit of the (right) translation action of H on G. Explicitly, a coset gH is the set \{gh: h\in H\}. The set of cosets of H in G is written G/H.
A group action of G on A is transitive if it has a single orbit.
The stabiliizer of an element a of a G-set A is the subgroup of G which fixes a, i.e. \operatorname {stab}_G(a) := \{g\in G: g\cdot a = a\}.
Let H\leq G be a subgroup, and G/H the set of cosets of G. Then there is an equation of cardinalities |H||G/H| = |G|.
The cosets partition G, so it suffices to show that all cosets have cardinality |H|. The map H\to gH,\quad h\mapsto gh is a bijection, with inverse x\mapsto g^{-1}x.
Let A be a G-set and a\in A. Then there is an equation of cardinalities |\operatorname {stab}_G(a)||Ga| = |G|, where the former is the stabilizer and the latter is the orbit.

We construct a bijection Ga\cong G/\operatorname {stab}_G(a), whence the result follows from Lagrange's theorem. Given an element b = ga\in Ga, identify it with the coset g\operatorname {stab}_G(a). This is well-defined: if b = ga = ha, then gh^{-1}\in \operatorname {stab}_G(a), so that g\operatorname {stab}_G(a) = h\operatorname {stab}_G(a). Moreover, it is injective: if g\operatorname {stab}_G(a) = h\operatorname {stab}_G(a), then gh^{-1} \in \operatorname {stab}_G(a), so that ga = ha. Finally, it is surjective: given some g\operatorname {stab}_G(a), it is the image of ga\in Ga.
An action of G on A is equivalently a functor from the associated category to G to Set which sends the unique object of G to A.
A subgroup N is normal, i.e. the kernel of a map f, if and only if it is closed under conjugation. We write N\unlhd G.
Most authors take this latter condition as the definition of normal subgroups.

fr:title.text: Congruences of groups are equivalently normal subgroups

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Congruences of groups are equivalently normal subgroups

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a group. Then the data of a congruence on G is equivalent to the data of a normal subgroup of G.

Given a normal subgroup N, define the relation g\sim h if and only if gh^{-1} \in N, i.e. if and only if their left cosets agree. This is a congruence, i.e., a subgroup of the product G\times G, by normality of N. Conversely, given a congruence \sim , define the subgroup N consisting of those g\in G such that g\sim e, where e is the unit of G. These constructions are inverses.
Let N\unlhd G. Then the quotient group G/N is the quotient object of the induced congruence; explicitly, it is the set of cosets of N in G with the operation (gN)(hN) = (gh)N.

To show that this defines a group, note that the induced equivalence relation is a congruence, hence compatible with the group multiplication, so that the multiplication is well-defined. The group axioms are direct from those of G.

To exhibit the universal property, let G\xrightarrow {f} H be any homomorphism which is constant on equivalence classes. Since G/N is also the quotient set, It suffices to show that the induced set-function \tilde {f} is a homomorphism: \tilde {f}(ghN) = f(gh) = f(g)f(h) = \tilde {f}(g)\tilde {f}(h).
Grp is regular.
Let G\xrightarrow {\varphi } H be a group homomorphism. Then there is an isomorphism G/\ker (\varphi ) \cong \operatorname {im}(\varphi ). of the quotient of the kernel and the image.
Grp is regular; this is the statement of (regular epi, mono) factorization.

A presentation \langle A \mid R\rangle of a group G consists of a set A, a set R of words in A, and a surjective homomorphism FA\twoheadrightarrow G from the free group FA with kernel R, in particular realizing G as the quotient of FA by the normal subgroup generated by R.

Let G be a group and N\unlhd G. Then there is a lattice isomorphism between the lattice of subgroups of G containing N and the lattice of subgroups of the quotient G/N, which sends N\leq A\leq G to A/N. Moreover, this assignment preserves and reflects normality.
Let G\xrightarrow {\varphi } H be a group homomorphism. Then there is an isomorphism G/\ker (\varphi ) \cong \operatorname {im}(\varphi ). of the quotient of the kernel and the image.
Grp is regular; this is the statement of (regular epi, mono) factorization.
An epimorphism is regular if it is a coequalizer. Dually, a monomorphism is regular if it is an equalizer.
A category is regular if:

fr:ul.fr:li: regular epimorphisms have pullbacks and their pullbacks are regular.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An epimorphism of groups is just a surjective homomorphism.
First, if G\xrightarrow {e} H is a surjective homomorphism, then given homomorphisms H\overset {f, g}{\rightrightarrows } K, we have that f = g because e is an epi in Set, so e is an epi.

Second, let G\xrightarrow {e} H be an epi in Grp. We wish to find a group K and two maps H\overset {f, g}{\rightrightarrows } K which agree on the image of e, hence are equal, in such a way that their equality allows us to conclude surjectivity of e. Let K be the symmetric group of the set of cosets H/e(G) with an adjoined point *.

Let H\xrightarrow {f} K be the map which sends h\in H to the associated permutation acting on kH by left translation and fixing *. Let \sigma \in K be the permutation which exchanges e(G) and *; let g be f composed with the inner automorphism associated to \sigma .

We finally claim that f(e(a)) = g(e(a)) for each a\in G. Indeed, since e(a)\in e(G), e(a) fixes e(G) and *, so is fixed under conjugation by \sigma . Now since e is an epi, f = g. Thus for each b\in H, f(b) = g(b), so that g(b) fixes f(H), i.e. bf(H) = f(H), so b\in f(H), as desired.
Let N\unlhd G. Then the quotient group G/N is the quotient object of the induced congruence; explicitly, it is the set of cosets of N in G with the operation (gN)(hN) = (gh)N.

To show that this defines a group, note that the induced equivalence relation is a congruence, hence compatible with the group multiplication, so that the multiplication is well-defined. The group axioms are direct from those of G.

To exhibit the universal property, let G\xrightarrow {f} H be any homomorphism which is constant on equivalence classes. Since G/N is also the quotient set, It suffices to show that the induced set-function \tilde {f} is a homomorphism: \tilde {f}(ghN) = f(gh) = f(g)f(h) = \tilde {f}(g)\tilde {f}(h).
As for any monadic category, Grp is complete, and moreover its limits are created from Set.
The category of groups Grp is the category whose objects are groups and whose morphisms are homomorphisms.
The kernel pair of a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y is the pullback of f along itself:

fr:title.text: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
A pullback is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet .
The symbol \lrcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pullback.
